Headline: UPDATE: India ICICI Bank Prices Public Offer At INR940/Share
Story: (Updates an item published at 1259 GMT with company confirmation, comments, more details and analyst comments)     By Romit Guha   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--ICICI Bank Ltd. (532174.BY), India's largest private bank by assets, Saturday said it has priced its domestic follow-on public offer at INR940 per share and its American Depository Receipts issue at $49.25 per unit.   The combined public offer, through which the company is aiming to raise $4.29 billion, excluding the greenshoe options, is the largest ever fund raising exercise by an Indian company and has evoked strong interest from overseas and domestic investors.   The offer tops that by state-run Oil & Natural Gas Corp. in 2004, which raised INR105.42 billion ($2.58 billion).   The INR87.50-billion domestic part of the offer is by itself India's second largest after ONGC.   "This (issue) is a huge vote of confidence for ICICI Bank, India's economy and its growth story," Arjun Khullar, managing director at J.P. Morgan said.   Deven Choksey, managing director at Mumbai-based KR Choksey Shares & Securities Pvt. Ltd., described the pricing as a "fair one for investors."   ICICI Bank had set an indicative price band of INR885-INR950 for its follow-on public offer, subscriptions for which opened June 19 and closed Friday.   Its shares closed Friday 0.4% higher at INR953.75.   The overall issue was subscribed 11.5 times the offer of 98.87 million shares.   The qualified institutional buyers portion was subscribed 21.6 times, the non-institutional investors section was subscribed nearly 6.1 times, while the portion earmarked for retail investors was subscribed one time.   "Foreign investors still see a lot of growth in Indian industrial credit and corporate growth," said Khullar.   He added about one-third of the subscriptions had come in from Asia - primarily Singapore and Hong Kong, about 15% from the Middle East, about 30% from Europe and about 20% from the U.S.   "Foreign demand is less price sensitive than retail demand," said Khullar.   People close to the development had earlier said that principal bidders included Singapore's Temasek Holdings, Goldman Sachs (GS) and private equity firm Warburg Pincus.   Choksey expects the "effects of stock dilution" to limit ICICI Bank's gains to the INR975 levels for about six months, but expects its growth to push the price to about INR1,025 around a year from now.   The bank's local offer has a greenshoe option worth INR13.13 billion, while the $2.14-billion overseas offer has a greenshoe option worth $320 million.   The bank didn't specify whether the greenshoe options will be exercised.   A "greenshoe" is a clause in an underwriting agreement saying that, in the event of exceptional public demand, the issuer will authorize additional shares for distribution.   ICICI Bank's offer comes at a time when major Indian lenders are looking to raise funds.   State Bank of India (500112.BY), ICICI Bank's biggest competitor and the country's largest bank by assets, plans to raise INR140 billion-INR150 billion in the current financial year.   HDFC Bank Ltd. (500180.BY) is in the process of raising $1 billion via a preferential issue and a public offer in the domestic and international markets and Industrial Development Bank of India (500116.BY) is also planning to raise $1.5 billion via overseas debt.   ICICI bank is planning to use the funds from the sale to expand its consumer credit, corporate business and rural-agri business, Kalpana Morparia, ICICI Group's chief strategy and communication officer said earlier.   "The growth in India's economy is being fueled by the financial liberalization program and that is creating new opportunities from domestic banks," said Patti McLaughlin, vice-chairman at investment banking, DSP Merrill Lynch.     -By Romit Guha, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 12:46 ET (16:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Top Of The Market
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Blackstone's initial public offering Thursday marked the most important debut for any company since Google went public in 2004. Just as Google changed the rules of the game in Internet search and dealt a sharp blow to newspapers and other traditional media, the Blackstone Group, the world's most prominent private-equity firm, is reshaping the corporate landscape and helping to fuel a global bull market in stocks through its appetite for leveraged buyouts.   Blackstone isn't another Google, however, and is unlikely to see its shares -- or, more precisely, its limited-partnership units -- quintuple in coming years, as Google (ticker: GOOG) famously did. To the contrary, Blackstone (BX) may well disappoint investors, notwithstanding its stellar performance Friday, and its IPO may signal the absolute top of the buyout boom. The stock opened at 37, above its offering price of 31, and finished the day at 35.06, endowing the New York-headquartered firm with a market value of $38 billion. Blackstone's high-profile CEO, Steve Schwarzman, now is worth over $9 billion, thanks to first-day gains in Blackstone shares.   By almost any financial yardstick, Blackstone looks richly valued relative to other asset managers, especially at a time when rising interest rates and burgeoning competition threaten to make the buyout business tougher. Indeed, the IPO could prove a high-water mark for the private-equity business.   A rising stock market has made compelling takeover targets scarcer for both private and corporate buyers, even as more rivals, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs, crowd the field and eye the same ripe targets. Higher rates and more conservative lending standards likewise threaten to make life more expensive for borrowers and deal-doers of all stripes.   As Wall Street veteran Seth Klarman of Baupost Group wrote in a letter to investors earlier this year about the surge in alternative assets, private-equity included: "There are no magic investments that make money for you no matter what you pay for them. The more you pay, the less the return; the greater the competition, the less the inefficiency."   What's more, even when private-equity firms identify targets, gaining control is getting more difficult and costly because once-spineless institutional investors are starting to view LBOs as thefts of public companies.   Witness the financial concessions that a buyout group led by Bain and Thomas H. Lee Partners is making to emboldened holders of Clear Channel Communications (CCU) in a bid to acquire the radio giant. Two weeks don't make a trend, but the first half of June marked the slowest period for mergers and acquisitions since January, according to Thomson Financial.   But neither these concerns nor Washington's threat to enact rules that would raise Blackstone's taxes deterred the firm's large underwriting group, led by Morgan Stanley, from pricing 133 million of Blackstone's limited-partnership units Thursday night, five days ahead of schedule. On heavy demand, the deal priced at the top of its expected range of $29 to $31 per unit, although one buyer was able to scoop up shares at a 4.5% discount: Concurrent with the IPO, an investment arm of the Chinese government purchased a $3 billion stake in the firm.   The public offering was a coup for Schwarzman, 60, and other Blackstone partners, who now own about 75% of the company's shares -- stock for which they paid nothing, at least in monetary terms. The deal gives Blackstone a currency to make acquisitions and raise money for investments in its private-equity, real-estate and hedge funds. Schwarzman and Pete Peterson, Blackstone's co-founder and senior chairman, probably can't believe their good fortune. A few years ago, a Blackstone IPO might have had trouble getting done at all, given the weaker market environment and novelty of the idea of taking a private-equity outfit public.   Blackstone executives declined to comment for this article.   The bullish case for Blackstone is that it's led by some of the smartest people in the investment business. Blackstone managed $88 billion on May 1, up from $14 billion at the end of 2001, and stands to earn high returns while risking little or none of its own capital. So far, it has delivered handsomely for investors: Its private-equity funds, which control $33 billion, have returned 22.6% annually (after fees) since 1987, double the Standard & Poor's 500 index's gain.   How has Blackstone done it? Its 2004 purchase of Celanese, a chemicals concern, is a textbook example of an LBO score. Blackstone recognized that Celanese, though a U.S. company, had shares that were traded mainly in Germany, where chemical-company valuations were lower. The firm won control of Celanese for $4 billion and quickly took it public, arbitraging the valuation gap between the U.S. and European markets -- and getting help from an upturn in the chemicals business. Blackstone had a fivefold return on its investment, evidence of the magic of a smart acquisition financed with lots of debt.   The bearish case for Blackstone rests in good part on valuation. At 35, the company is valued at about 32 times 2006 profits, five times book value and 43% of its assets under management.   The buzz is that Blackstone has quietly been guiding investors to a projection of 2008 profits of about $1.75 a share, which means the stock trades in line with the valuation of Blackstone's only publicly traded peer, Fortress Investment Group [FIG], an operator of hedge funds and private-equity funds that went public in February. Fortress shares trade around 24.   Trading for 20 times projected 2008 earnings, Blackstone looks rich relative to Wall Street's biggest securities firms -- Goldman Sachs (GS), Bear Stearns (BSC), Morgan Stanley (MS), Merrill Lynch (MER) and Lehman Brothers (LEH) -- which fetch an average of 10 times their estimated '08 earnings. Asset managers like T. Rowe Price (TROW) and Franklin Resources (BEN) are valued at about 18 times estimated '08 earnings. Put a price-earnings multiple of 15 on Blackstone's estimated 2008 earnings and the stock would be trading in the mid-20s.   Assets managers typically sell for 2% to 5% of their managed investments. Blackstone has a higher market value than Franklin Resources. Yet Franklin manages $620 billion, seven times Blackstone's asset base.   What is crucially different is that Blackstone enjoys much higher fees than traditional asset managers, owing to the 20% incentive fee it gets on clients' gains. But such fees, which account for most of its earnings, could now be unsustainably high.   In the past, investors in companies such as Man Group, the British hedge-fund operator, effectively assigned a lower price-earnings multiple to incentive fees than base fees because of greater uncertainty about the sustainability of incentives. No such discount has been applied to Blackstone. Although the firm has made no big missteps in recent years, the odds are rising that it will be stung by one or more of its leveraged buyouts in coming years. A blowup could damage its reputation, hurt its stock, depress fees and hurt its ability to raise new funds.   Blackstone's financial statements are tough to read because of a host of adjustments the firm makes to its earnings, based on partners' compensation, equity grants and taxes. A key profit measure is "pro forma economic net income" -- $1.2 billion after taxes in 2006. Dividing that amount into the company's $38 billion market value yields a P/E of 32.   Blackstone had a blockbuster first quarter, earning $640 million in economic net income, half of what it made in all of 2006. Its latest good fortune owed largely to huge profits from its real-estate funds. Blackstone's earnings are apt to be lumpy, since they hinge on its timing in harvesting gains in its portfolio and realizing its 20% incentive fee. But the firm can earn pretty much whatever it wants in coming quarters, given already-embedded gains in its investments.   A key risk to Blackstone's shares is the threat of higher taxes. In its prospectus, Blackstone assumed a 17% tax rate for last year (when state as well as federal taxes are taken into account), but that could rise by 20 percentage points if Congress moves to force the firm into a corporate structure. Iowa Republican Charles Grassley has introduced a bill in the Senate to do just that, arguing Blackstone shouldn't benefit from a low tax rate relative to other asset managers and Wall Street firms. If Grassley and others get their wish, higher taxes probably won't bite for several years. Still, if Blackstone were paying a full corporate tax rate, its P/E, based on 2006 earnings, would be nearly 40.   House Democrats took aim Friday at another tax break enjoyed by partners in private-equity firms that enables them to treat as a capital gain the "carried interest," or 20% profit, they earn on increases in their firms' investment funds. This income is taxed at the preferential 15% federal capital-gains rate, rather than the top 35% levy on ordinary income. Capital gains get favorable treatment because the government wants to reward investment and compensate investors for risk. But Blackstone risks none of its own capital to get its carry fees.   Schwarzman may have himself to blame for Washington's sudden focus on his industry's tax treatment. While most private-equity, hedge-fund and Wall Street chieftains prefer a low profile, he craves the limelight. He threw himself a lavish party when he turned 60 in February. He lives in one of New York's poshest apartments, in the best address on Park Avenue. And in a recent interview with The Wall Street Journal, he described takeover battles in military terms, saying: "I want war, not a series of skirmishes. I always think about what will kill off the other bidder."   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: ICICI Bank Prices Public Offer At INR940/Shr - Source
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--ICICI Bank Ltd. (532174.BY), India's largest private bank by assets, Saturday priced its follow-on public offering at INR940 per share, a merchant banker close to the issue said.   ICICI Bank had set an indicative price band of INR885-INR950 for its follow-on public offering last Saturday.   The bank will raise INR92.94 billion ($2.28 billion) at the issue price.   The overall issue was subscribed 12.3 times the offer of 98.87 million shares at close Friday. The issue had opened for subscription June 19.   The qualified institutional buyers portion was subscribed 23.2 times, the non-institutional investors section was subscribed nearly 6.5 times, while the portion earmarked for retail investors was subscribed 1.1 times.     -By Romit Guha, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 08:59 ET (12:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from June 14 through 20.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     PHH (PHH)   Pennant Capital Management reiterated its "strong objections" to the company's proposed merger with GE Capital Solutions and Blackstone Group. The investor said it wants PHH to provide shareholders with the information required to understand alternatives to the proposed sale by filing a definitive proxy statement that "alleviates the gaping holes" in the preliminary statement. Pennant Capital currently holds 4,169,800 shares (7.8% of the total outstanding).     Synovics Pharmaceuticals (SYVC)   Nostrum Pharmaceuticals plans to nominate three candidates for election to Synovics' board at its annual meeting, scheduled for Aug. 17. The nominees would be Nirmal V. Mulye, Michael T. Newhouse and Sachin Tikekar. Nostrum previously said it wasn't satisfied with the performance of current management, noting its failure to take steps to maximize shareholder value. Nostrum has 10,661,000 shares (35.99%).     RMR Hospitality and Real Estate Fund (RHR)   RMR Hospitality said that the legal expenses it incurred in its litigation with Bulldog Investors General Partnership "are the result of the tactics" employed by the hedge fund. RMR said in November that it had sued shareholder Bulldog Investors to enforce a provision of the company's bylaws that restricts ownership by any shareholder or group of shareholders to 9.8%.   Bulldog Investors said that amounts spent by the company in its legal dispute with the hedge fund "have already had a materially adverse impact on the fund's net asset value." Bulldog Investors holds 243,400 shares (9.79%).     InfoTech USA (IFTH)   Applied Digital Solutions (ADSX) said that it has been in contact with a third party regarding a potential sale of all or substantially all of the shares of its majority owned subsidiary, InfoTech USA.   Applied Digital Solutions said that it plans to continue discussions and efforts toward evaluating and possibly effecting such a transaction. Applied Digital owns 2.57 million shares (50.9%).     ITC Deltacom (ITCD)   H Partners Capital strongly opposes a recapitalization plan recently announced by the company. H Partners said the recapitalization plan "disenfranchises minority shareholders and allows insiders and other parties to profit at their expense." H Partners Capital holds 1.2 million shares (6.4%).     Lancaster Colony (LANC)   Barington Cos. Equity Partners wants the company to dispose of its automotive, glassware and candle businesses. Barington said the company's "failure to promptly divest these business segments has prolonged the time" that Lancaster has operated under an "inefficient 'holding company' structure," which has imposed additional expenses on the company and its shareholders.   Barington owns about 1.66 million shares (5.29%).     Original Filings     Numerex (NMRX)   A group including Rye 68 reported ownership of 686,000 shares (5.26%), after buying 500,000 in a privately negotiated transaction from Kenneth Manswer, a former director of the company, on June 19 at $8.25 a share.     Apex Silver Mines (SIL)   Norges Bank (the central bank of Norway) reported ownership of 2,996,116 shares (5.1%). No transaction details were provided.     Increases in Holdings     Arbinet-thexchange (ARBX)   Investor Karen Singer raised her stake in the company to 2.4 million shares (9.44%), from the 1.8 million (7.04%) reported on May 8.     Decreases in Holdings     Energy Conversion Devices (ENER)   Coghill Capital Management lowered its holdings to about 3 million shares (7.5%), from the 3.66 million (9.2%) reported on June 11.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Yemeni Guard Shoots Occidental Oil Employees, 1 Dead
Story: (Updates with security official saying victims were coming off a plane at time of shooting)     SAN'A, Yemen (AP)--A Yemeni guard opened fire Saturday at the employees of an international oil company in Yemen, killing an Indian national and seriously wounding an American, two Britons, a Tunisian and a Yemeni man, security and local officials said.   The incident took place at the Occidental Petroleum Corp. (OXY) in the Shabwa province in the south of the country, some 500 kilometers (300 miles) south of the capital, San'a.   Shabwa province governor, Ali al-Maqqdishi, identified the guard as Jamel Mohammed el-Raaie, and said he was mentally disturbed.   A Yemeni security official, speaking on condition of anonymity because he was not allowed to give statements to media, said the wounded were transferred to a hospital in the Yemeni capital, San'a, for treatment.   The official said that the victims were all coming off a plane that was landing at the oil company's airstrip in Shabwa when the guard randomly opened fire at them.   The victims' names were not known. An employee reached by phone at the press office of the U.S. embassy in San'a declined to comment on the incident, but said that a warden notice would be posted on the embassy's Web site within an hour. No further details were immediately available.   Occidental Petroleum Corp. is a California-based international company with oil and gas operations in three core areas - the United States, Latin America and the Middle East, including Yemen.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 10:31 ET (14:31 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Commodities Corner: Staking Bids In Brazilian Steak
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kenneth Rapoza   Brazilian beef dominates world markets. To cash in on the current gravy train, Brazil's family-dominated beef dynasties are going public. For small-cap investors with an appetite for emerging-market stocks, the lineup of initial public offerings is enticing. And analysts see very promising upside for Brazilian meat companies overall.   The latest example: the March 28 IPO of JBS (ticker: JBSS3.Brazil), which owns Friboi Group -- the largest meatpacker in Latin Americaand soon-to-be proud parent of Swift & Co., the fifth-largest meat outfit in the U.S.   Marfrig (MRFG3.Brazil), Brazil's No. 3 beef exporter, will list on Bovespa, the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, on June 28, with Americans who meet the SEC's 144A rules qualified to invest. The fourth-largest beef exporter, Minerva, has announced that it will list common shares on Bovespa's Novo Mercado system-the exchange's most rigorous and transparent form of stock listing-later this year. Bertin Group, the No. 2 beef exporter in Brazil, is also toying with the idea of an IPO. Investment funds from JPMorgan, Credit Suisse First Boston and Santander Investment all have a stake.   Nearly three-fourths of JBS/Friboi's IPO shares were gobbled up by foreigners. They now trade around 7.30 Brazilian reals, or $3.80, below the IPO value of BRL8 per share, with the drop mostly due to expansion costs. JBS' first-quarter net revenue was BRL1.1 billion, 22.6% above the level a year earlier. Export revenue was BRL626 million, up 24.8%.   In the quarter, growth in Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) was 28.4%. The Ebitda margin was 14.4%, versus 3.14% for multinational Tyson Foods (TSN). Since its IPO, JBS' average share volume has outstripped Tyson's by about 10%.   While it's hard to compare Friboi's corporate structure to U.S. peers', Brazil's dominant meat companies look like cheap bets in a growing market, as developing-world populations eat more animal protein. Brazil, the world's top beef exporter, boasts record export volume (over $3 billion annually) the past two years -- despite a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak leading to a 56-nation ban, mostly on meat from the states where sick cattle were reported. Companies such as Bertin and Friboi have used ban-free states to keep the cash flowing in. Brazil exported 1.2 million metric tons of fresh beef in 2006, versus 1.08 million tons in '05, according to its foreign trade ministry.   "Sanitation risks are the biggest barriers to success for these companies. That's something Friboi and Bertin can't really predict or control," says Amaryelles Romano, a food-sector analyst for consultants Tendencias in Sao Paulo. "Other than that, this sector's outlook is extremely positive," she adds.   Brazil's most-traded meat companies, Sadia and Perdigao, both have American depositary receipts traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the respective tickers SDA and PDA. Both companies are expanding. Perdigao just announced a $49 million investment in a beef-packing facility in Mato Grosso state, home to Brazil's second-largest cattle herd.   "The IPO markets are a positive, because companies like Bertin can use them to pay back bond holders. They will tend to invest capital-market cash in capacity expansion and acquisitions, which bodes well for long-term revenue," says Isabela Bacchi, a bond analyst from the emerging-markets credit research team at JPMorgan Securities in New York.   ---   Kenneth Rapoza is a reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in Sao Paulo.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Vice Chmn Doesn't Rule Out Eni Role In Shtokman Proj
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--Alexander Medvedev, vice chairman of OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS), Saturday didn't rule out a role for Eni SpA (E), Italy's biggest oil company by volume, over joining the giant Shtokman gas field in Russia.   Medvedev said Gazprom and Eni may develop further cooperation deals between the two as part of their strategic alliance when asked by Dow Jones Newswires regarding the possibility of Eni taking part in the Shtokman project.   The Gazprom executive was speaking at a press conference in Rome for the signing of a memorandum of understanding between the two companies on the possibility of building a new pipeline called "South Stream," bringing Russian gas to the European Union.   Eni and the Russian gas behemoth signed a strategic agreement in November extending supplies of gas to the Rome-based company to 2035 while allowing Gazprom to sell directly certain quantities of the fossil fuel in Italy. Among other items agreed was the possibility of allowing Eni to enter Russia's upstream market.   Earlier this month, people familiar with the matter said Eni has had preliminary contacts with Gazprom over joining the Shtokman project in Russia's Barents Sea.   Joining Shtokman "has been talked about at high levels (between Eni and Gazprom), but it has been a recent discussion, not one that's advanced," a Moscow-based official familiar with the two companies' operations told Dow Jones Newswires June 1.   Gazprom had previously preselected partners for minority stakes in the Shtokman project, but in October the Russian firm changed tack and said it would keep 100% equity control over the project, with foreign partners involved only as contractors.   Natural gas exports from the massive Shtokman gas field are set to begin to flow to Europe in 2013, with LNG deliveries to North America due to start in 2014. The field boasts some 3.7 trillion cubic meters of gas.   Separately, Medvedev also said Gazprom may decide not to exercise the option it holds to buy the 20% stake Eni owns in Russian company OAO Gazprom Neft (SIBN.RS) depending on the outcome of talks with the Italian company on how to expand their alliance accord of November.   Gazprom has two years to exercise the option.     -By Liam Moloney, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 678 2543; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 12:08 ET (16:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Staying Out Of Trouble
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With Arnie Schneider   Founder and Chief Investment Officer, Schneider Capital Management     Call it greatness. Call it gifted. Call the consistently outstanding stock-picking performance all in a day's work for Schneider and his team at Schneider Capital Management of Wayne, Pa., who manage $6.3 billion. Dedicated to finding deeply undervalued stocks on the verge of cyclical change, Schneider's funds have outshone their benchmarks and most competitors year after year after year. As of May 31, the Schneider Small Cap had average, since its start in September 1998, compared with 15% for the Russell 2000 Value index. The Schneider Value Fund (SCMLX) was up 29.2% annually, on average, since its start in October 2002, versus 20.1% for the Russell 1000 Value index. That's what greatness looks like. This is what it sounds like.     Barron's: Last year, you likened the market to Lake Wobegon, where all stocks were priced above average. What do you make of this year's market?   Schneider: I don't have any cute lines for it, but it seems late in the bull-market cycle. The market is priced for perfection. It seems to me that the market is assuming that credit spreads stay low and therefore the private-equity boom continues. It also seems to assume that the U.S. economy avoids a recession and that the very rapid international economic growth continues. Collectively, the risks are high that one of those ends, and if one does then the bull market is over. If I were to hazard a guess, I would say it is the credit-spreads, private-equity boom that is the most important driver of the three.     Q: With interest rates rising, aren't we starting to see more concern about spreads and private-equity funding?   A: Yes, that is the first threat to the private-equity boom. Credit costs have gone up and that's making acquisitions more expensive. Wider credit spreads will be the second nail in the coffin. Last year, 8 1/2% of the U.S. market was leveraged-buyout-related, which was similar to peaks in the late 1990s and late '80s. That's a pretty big number.     Q: How are you approaching the market, given the risks?   A: The value markets are very difficult now because there are very few valuation differentials to exploit, and so we have concentrated our portfolios on our best ideas to a greater degree. We are focused increasingly in the financial area because it is one of the last remaining areas that is cheap. It is an area where we can find earnings streams that are still low and have the availability to improve, as opposed to paying big multiples on earnings streams that are not durable, in our judgment. There are opportunities in names that are high-quality institutions that should do well, irrespective of the housing debacle, and in some cases will benefit as their weaker competitors that lost their way move aside.     Q: What are your expectations for the economy?   A: The risks of a domestic recession have risen with this bond-market back-up. The consumer is very fragile. Consumers, who are two-thirds of the economy, have hung in there, although clearly at a decelerating rate. They're the $64,000 question for which direction the economy goes. Exports are leading the economy, housing is dragging the economy and the consumer will be the ultimate arbiter of whether we avoid a recession or not. Employment has been slowing but is still solid. We are averaging about 130,000 jobs a month this year, which is down by about one-third from last year but not too bad. And incomes are growing nicely, so the consumer has hung in there. We were spending well above incomes and consumers, probably correctly, have ratcheted their spending down to equal their incomes. I think the next move is for spending to move below income growth, mostly because we've got the first housing-price depreciation since the Great Depression. It is just inconsistent to me that home builders are trading at new lows and retailing stocks are trading at new highs. That isn't the way the economy works. They're more closely linked than that.     Q: But why the disconnect?   A: I think the reason is that 94% of homeowners have over 10% equity in their homes. They have unrealized losses versus a year ago, but they still have realized gains in their homes and they are not forced sellers. As long as they have a job, consumers are going to continue to spend and be confident, and that is why we are most likely to avoid a recession. But the foundation is weaker.   If you look at the financial-obligations ratio, it is at an all-time high. Mortgage-equity withdrawal is half its peak level, but it is still way above normal and there are lags there. The headwinds on the consumer have started and they are gathering, but it takes a shock to tumble the economy into a recession. Again, the most likely outcome is avoidance of a recession, but the odds have clearly gone up.     Q: Are you looking not only for stocks that are inexpensive but also defensive?   A: Ideally, you would like to find those. The problem is the true defensive stocks -- the utilities and stocks of that nature -- are very expensive. Playing pure defense is too expensive to do. We haven't found a lot of pure defensive stocks. The food stocks are 17 times earnings. The telephone stocks are not cheap.     Q: What about Big Pharma?   A: Pharma is defensive and the stocks are statistically cheap, unlike the others. But the question there is, what's the growth rate? Congress is attacking their franchise and there are a lot of patent expirations going on. So the growth rates in earnings over the next few years are quite sluggish.     Q: So you're focused on financials, and what else?   A: Coal.     Q: Let's start with the financials.   A: The first name is Countrywide Financial [ticker: CFC]. Countrywide is the largest and arguably the most efficient mortgage originator and servicer in the country. They've got an integrated operation and can respond quickly to changing industry conditions. Their servicing portfolio represents about 15% of U.S. mortgage debt outstanding. The key to this stock is that the current mortgage-industry turmoil should lead to less competition and more rational pricing. The pricing has been very, very thin, really throughout the mortgage chain, so they'll be a direct beneficiary of better spreads, which are already emerging in mortgages. Also, Countrywide has diversified into several new businesses in the last decade that should smooth out the earnings stream and provide some balance for the mortgage operation.     Q: If we are looking at a possible recession and a bottom in the housing market has yet to occur, won't there be more pain for people who invest in this stock now?   A: That's the point. I look at 2007 as the trough year for their earnings. Mortgage margins are extremely low. Originations are down by over a third from the peak in 2003. The new-home market is extraordinarily weak and the refi market is somewhat weak, and so we view mortgage spreads as being at a low. We view mortgage originations as being at a low. We think volumes will go up next year and spreads will go up next year as competitors exit. Even if housing starts go down next year, Countrywide's earnings likely would go up. Remember, they are generating tremendous amounts of capital. This year they are going to earn a 15% return on equity on trough earnings. Their capital base will grow, enabling them to grow earnings.     Q: Let's talk about the numbers.   A: The market expects them to earn $3.80 this year, which we think is the trough year of earnings. The stock is 10 times trough earnings, and trough earnings have a 15% return on equity. Over time, ROE has averaged in the high teens to low 20s, so earnings power clearly is higher, not only as the capital base grows but as the return on equity returns to median levels.     Q: Any other financials?   A: The other pick is Luminent Mortgage Capital [LUM], a small-cap mortgage REIT. Luminent is different than Countrywide in that they don't originate mortgages. They are just a disciplined buyer of mortgage product and can sit on the sidelines when spreads are tight. When spreads are wide, as they were in March and April, they can buy as much as their balance sheet allows. Luminent is selling below book value, and it is a fairly hard book.     Q: A hard book?   A: It's solid. The portfolio is marked to market at the end of the quarter. They have very strong credit management. Their portfolio is showing significantly better credit performance than portfolios with similar metrics, and the stock is selling for a whopping six times Wall Street's estimated '08 earnings. They are buying back stock and, most important, they benefit from the wider credit spreads, mortgage spreads that have existed since February.     Q: Does Luminent pay a dividend?   A: Yes, it's yielding more than 12%.     Q: On to coal. What's to like?   A: Coal has a promising future. Last year was kind of a perfect storm for the coal industry. There was a warm winter and a cool summer, strong hydroelectric and relatively low natural-gas prices. Demand was weak and in response to the strong coal prices in 2004 and 2005, supply was in the process of really ramping up. Inventories exploded, prices collapsed and stock prices collapsed. Coal is now in the process of reversing the ugly 2006 trends.     Q: What's changing?   A: There are three main regions of the coal industry: the Powder River Basin in the West; the North Appalachian area; and Central Appalachian, which is the high-cost area in the U.S. Under current conditions, Central App is shutting down capacity. They are about 20% of U.S. production. Year to date, Central App production is down about 20 million tons, and we think it will be down about twice that for the entire year. More Central App capacity will shut in 2008 because most coal contracts are multiyear.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Streetwise: Of Dangerous Books And Markets
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   One of the summer's two surprise nonfiction bestsellers is The Dangerous Book for Boys. The other, The Black Swan, might as well be called The Book for Dangerous Boys, so popular has it become among the same hedge-fund traders and sell-siders the author blames for raising the odds of a catastrophic financial surprise.   The former book is a nostalgic guide to traditional boyhood games and hobbies, meant to teach Wii-addicted, over-scheduled kids about supposedly simpler pleasures. The latter, a treatise on the way dramatic chance occurrences shape the world, instructs us to mistrust high-tech models and statistical assumptions.   The Black Swan -- by the trader and scholar Nassim Nicholas Taleb -- was spotted on a few lounge chairs last week at a beach resort favored by Wall Streeters, within reach of well-thumbed BlackBerrys.   It is No. 24 among all books on www.amazon.com, and the site says its buyers also commonly ordered Inside the House of Money: Top Hedge Fund Traders on Profiting in the Global Markets. Clearly, it's the season's beach read among the trading set.   The book (reviewed in Barron's Balancing the Books, June 4) is worthwhile. It's a learned, provocative, consensus-challenging work, if also a bit repetitive and strident. The essential point is that humans underestimate the frequency and impact of unforeseeable events, underweight the importance of luck in life and take false comfort in illusory patterns. Financial types come in for particular scorn.   But what does it suggest about the present market moment that this book has found such a ready audience in the investment world? What would it mean if "everyone" began going around "expecting the unexpected"?   Here's guessing that the lessons of the book will become oversimplified and misapplied. Before long, research reports and market commentaries will make "black swan" an overused buzz phrase, as they did "tipping point." And, more concretely, perhaps even more traders will look to hedge against known, conceivable risks -- a 10% stock-market correction, a subprime-mortgage rupture -- rather than open their minds to the utterly unpredictable occurrence.   This would fit with an already-active tack among hedge funds to -- yes -- hedge, to keep some short exposure on the books at all times. Bernie Schaeffer of Schaeffer's Investment Research has noted the accumulation of protective options, with last week's open S&P 500 puts versus calls running near 12-month highs. NYSE short interest again was up in the latest month, by 6%. Even though this measure is in long-term ascent, Ned Davis Research notes the short-interest ratio has run above its recent trend range.   These nuggets are not meant to imply that "everyone's bearish," which is far from true. Funds are comfortably net long, and, as a group, professional investors are upbeat. Yet there remains an overlay of skepticism -- a just-in-case exposure to the downside -- that creates a high burden of proof for those arguing the market is near an important top. And it lays a bid underneath the market should a break come.   This all says nothing about the direction of, say, the next 5% move, mind you (though as Taleb would scream, handicapping such things is futile and even dishonest).   Last week's 2% loss seemed to show that with little earnings news, a slowdown in merger action and the prevailing concept of abundant liquidity challenged by a mortgage hedge-fund run aground, this market belongs to the sellers. Bottom line: Having risen 25% in value in the past year, the market could give back a good bit more before the broader uptrend is undermined.     Time was when successful chain retailers were all about growth -- square-footage growth, sales growth, market-share growth. Now, due to the demands of catalyst-obsessed professional investors, they are financial-engineering stories.   Last week Home Depot (ticker: HD) got its long-idle stock moving with a plan for an asset sale, debt issuance and a buyback of 25% of its market value. Best Buy's (BBY) CFO said on a conference call that his company would mull its capital structure in light of Home Depot's move. And Limited Brands (LTD) -- subject of a recent bullish Barron's feature ("Victoria's Real Secret," June 11) -- said it would cut 500 jobs, take on new debt and repurchase 10% of its equity.   These shifts make for more efficient balance sheets. But also recognize that these companies are borrowing in order to shrink themselves. This is late-bull-market and late-profit-cycle action, which is a net positive until the game stops.   Note that quality companies weren't buying back stock as the bear market was giving way to a bull phase in late 2002 and stocks were relatively cheap. Hindsight is 20/20. Generals and CFOs fight the last war. Before long, we'll be back to demanding, and paying for, true growth strategies.   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Longer-Term Study On Merck's Januvia Released
Story: By Jennifer Corbett Dooren     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--A study of Merck & Co.'s (MRK)diabetes drug Januvia showed the medication lowered a key measure of blood sugar when taken in combination with another common diabetes drug in patients followed for a year.   The study, to be released Saturday at the American Diabetes Association's annual meeting in Chicago, marks the first time one-year data involving the drug will be released. Previous data involved patients with type 2 diabetes who were followed for six months.   Patients in the year-long study were broken into various groups - those who took Januvia alone; those who took metformin, another common diabetes drug, and patients who received both drugs together. The study, which also looked at different doses of Januvia and metformin, involved 762 patients who had an average so-called A1C level of 8.7% at the study start.   A1C measures blood glucose or blood sugar for an average of two to three months. A level below 7% is considered good blood sugar or blood-glucose control for people with diabetes.    The study showed that 67% of patients taking a combination of 50 milligrams of Januvia and 1000 milligrams  metformin twice daily achieved an A1C level of less than 7%  compared to 44% of patients who took metformin alone. The study showed 48% of patients taking a combination of 50 milligrams of Januvia and 500 milligrams of metformin twice daily achieved an A1C level of less than 7% compared to 25% of patients on 500 milligrams of metformin alone. The study showed 23% of patients taking 100 milligrams of Januvia once a day reached an A1C level of 7% or below.   Januvia, approved by the Food and Drug Administration last October, is known as a DPP-4 inhibitor and so far is the only type of drug in its class that's on the U.S. market. In February, the FDA delayed the approval of a similar drug made by Novartis (NVS) called Galvus.   Drugs like Januvia work by increasing the level of so-called incretin hormones in the body that help lower the blood sugar or blood-glucose levels. They work in a different manner than blood-glucose-lowering drugs currently on the market, including sulfonylurea drugs, which stimulate the pancreas to release insulin, and metformin, which works on the liver to reduce blood sugar.   About 21 million Americans have diabetes, a disease characterized by high blood-glucose levels that result from the body's inability to use or produce insulin. Type 2 diabetes most often occurs in people who are older than 45 and overweight, although there has been an increase in younger patients in recent years.   Type 1 diabetes, often diagnosed in childhood, requires people to use insulin to manage their blood sugar levels. Many diabetics also have poor lipid profiles, which puts them at risk for cardiovascular disease. Diabetes also can lead to blindness, kidney disease and amputations.     -By Jennifer Corbett Dooren, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9294; Jennifer.Corbett@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 11:00 ET (15:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
