Headline: Barron's(6/25) Top Of The Market -2-
Story: Schwarzman appeared on the cover of Fortune earlier this year, under the headline "The New King of the Street." It may be worth recalling that not long after John Gutfreund, the head of Salomon Brothers in the late 1980s, was crowned King of the Street, he was forced out of his job in a Treasury-bond scandal in the early '90s.     There's plenty of irony in Blackstone's IPO, since Schwarzman and other private-equity executives regularly tout the supposed benefits that companies gain from being private. Because of strong investor demand, Blackstone has been able to get away with being "a different kind of public company," to borrow a phrase from the IPO prospectus. Blackstone will be run like a private partnership, and public investors will have no real say in how it is run.   Many individual investors might not realize that investing in Blackstone's shares could involve tax hassles. Because of the partnership structure, individual holders will owe tax on the company's full annual profits. The good news is that Blackstone plans to give investors the wherewithal to pay taxes by providing an ample annual dividend of $1.20 a share through the end of 2009, resulting in an initial yield on the shares of 3.4%. Thereafter, the company plans to pay out in dividends the bulk of its economic net income.   Individual investors in Blackstone will get a K-1 partnership tax form, not the more common 1099 tax form. They probably will have to ask the Internal Revenue Service for an extension to file their tax returns, because Blackstone doesn't expect to have a K-1 available by next April 1. Also, individuals could owe income taxes in multiple states, according to the prospectus.   No matter these potential headaches, buyers lined up last week to purchase stock in the hope Blackstone's money machine keeps whirring. The firm has done particularly well with its real-estate funds, which now manage $20 billion. They've returned 31% annually, after fees, since inception in 1992. That is extraordinary, although any good real-estate fund has done well in the bull market of the past 15 years. One of the leading real-estate investment trusts, Vornado Realty Trust (VNO), which focuses on the office market, has returned 25% annually since 1992.   Blackstone's blockbuster deal to purchase Equity Office Properties, the REIT founded by Sam Zell, for $39 billion in February demonstrates the benefits and potential pitfalls of highly leveraged investments.   After putting up just $3.5 billion of equity in the EOP deal, Blackstone's real-estate fund moved quickly to unload about $20 billion of properties at high prices, including a $7 billion Manhattan sale. Blackstone generated over $500 million of net investment profits from its real-estate funds in the first quarter, reflecting the EOP sales.   It's notable that Blackstone reported big gains even though it still owns about half the EOP portfolio. Trouble could be looming for Blackstone because the Morgan Stanley index of REIT stocks is down about 20% since the EOP deal closed. Will Blackstone take a mark-to-market loss on its remaining EOP properties to reflect the declining share price of office REITs like Vornado? Don't bet on it. In the prospectus, Blackstone says that since the end of the first quarter, its real-estate business continues "to be favorably affected" by market conditions. This assessment seems rosy; rising interest rates and tightening lending standards are stinging buyers of commercial real estate, including the purchaser of the Manhattan buildings sold by Blackstone.   Blackstone and other real-estate investors now face a threefold problem. Prices of office buildings, shopping malls and hotels have soared around the world. Cash yields on commercial real estate are in the 4%-to-6% range, half what they were in the late 1990s. At the same time, more money is chasing these properties. Just last week, Morgan Stanley closed on an $8 billion real-estate fund, while Goldman brought in $4 billion for a new fund. With rates rising, the leveraged real-estate game is much tougher.   An investment in Blackstone amounts to a bet on the ability of its private-equity and real-estate funds to continue generating high returns. These funds produced 80% of Blackstone's profits last year. The firm also manages $35 billion of so-called alternative-asset funds, including a $20 billion fund-of-funds, which involves farming money out to hedge-fund managers. Blackstone also has a financial-advisory business.   One little-noticed feature in Blackstone's private-equity funds is a "clawback" provision. If a fund generates sizable profits, producing an incentive fee for Blackstone, and then suffers losses on a subsequent investment, Blackstone may have to repay the incentive fee to the fund's investors.   New capital commitments to private-equity firms hit $140 billion last year, up from $41 billion in 1997, according to Thomson. Blackstone just finished raising a $19.6 billion fund.   The private-equity business might not have reached bubble status, but there are eerie parallels with the late 1990s' venture-capital boom, when investors sought the next eBay. Venture returns plummeted after 2000 due to a dearth of opportunities and much-reduced valuations for tech stocks.   Asked about private equity at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting in May, Warren Buffett offered this insight: "Due to the nature of private equity, it's not a bubble that will burst. They lock up their money for five to 10 years and buy businesses that don't price daily. It takes many years for the score to be put on the board, and the investors can't leave. It's not like leverage in marketable securities."   Buffett observed that the interests of the managers of private-equity funds aren't necessarily aligned with those of their investors. "If you have a $20 billion fund and get a 2% fee, you're getting $400 million a year. But you can't raise another fund with a straight face until you've invested it, so there's a great compulsion to invest it quickly so you can raise another fund and get more fees. I think it will be quite some time before disillusion sets in" among private-equity investors, Buffett continued, according to a transcript by investor Whitney Tilson.   Last week's IPO could portend public offerings by Blackstone's rivals, much as Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette's offering in 1970 "blazed the trail for Merrill Lynch and others," says Byron Wien, the chief investment strategist at Pequot Capital Management in New York. It may be difficult for private-equity firms to stay private because "the temptations of being public will be too great," he adds.   KKR soon may file for an IPO. Other firms that could be waiting in the wings are Carlyle Group, Citadel Investment and Apollo Management. But when smart people agree to sell their businesses, investors ought to be wary. Such was the case when Zell parted with Equity Office in February.   Blackstone may be ringing a bell for private equity. It is, after all, no Goldman Sachs -- which has been around for more than 100 years. A decade from now, Goldman probably will have found new ways to mint money. It's uncertain what Blackstone and Schwarzman will be doing. With a $38 billion market value, Blackstone is discounting highly profitable leveraged buyouts stretching well into the future. Based on the headwinds in its key businesses, Blackstone looks significantly overvalued.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Raytheon Protests L-3 Win In US Small Cargo Plane Bidding
Story: By Rebecca Christie   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     PARIS (Dow Jones)--Raytheon Co. (RTN) said Saturday it has filed a protest with the U.S. government over the outcome of a U.S. cargo plane competition that could be worth $6 billion or more to the winning contractors.   The U.S. Army and the U.S. Air Force recently picked L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. (LLL) for the Joint Cargo Aircraft, a small cargo plane sought for short-range transport missions. The winning bid offered the C-27J aircraft, made by Finmeccanica SpA's (FNC.MI) Alenia unit, with plans for Boeing Co. (BA) to start a U.S. assembly line.   Losing bidder Raytheon also offered a plane of European origin, the C-295 made by the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Co. (5730.FR). This week, company officials received a briefing on the contest outcome and decided to file a protest.   In a statement, Raytheon offered few clues about the basis for its challenge. "Raytheon filed a bid protest on Friday with the Goverment Accountability Office regarding the Joint Cargo Aircraft award announced June 13, 2007. We will have no further comment at this time," Raytheon said.   But earlier this week, Raytheon Chief Executive William Swanson said his company generally doesn't file a protest without good cause.   "You can only protest and win if the process was flawed," Swanson said in an interview with Dow Jones Newswires that took place before Raytheon had received its full post-competition briefing.   "Did they follow the process they said they were going to follow?" Swanson said. "If they made an incorrect assumption about your proposal that was clear, or if they evaluated something that wasn't spelled out in the criteria, then the process becomes flawed."   The JCA protest is yet another challenge for Pentagon weapons buyers, who already are wrestling with a series of contentious issues. The Air Force is enmeshed in a messy protest of its $15 billion CSAR-X helicopter competition that has included several rounds of legal filings. The small cargo plane contest could follow that model, or be resolved more quickly if GAO finds no grounds to sustain the protest.   Questions swirled around the JCA program at this week's Paris Air Show. L-3 and Alenia officials offered several scenarios for production rates and timelines. And it also isn't clear how many planes the Pentagon has on contract - the official announcement says "up to" 78.   Last week, the U.S. Army said the $2 billion in the Pentagon announcement was a "misprint" and that the cost of those planes will actually be more like $4 billion. Analysts said the $2 billion number might represent 54 planes headed for the Army, without any of the 24 planes designated for Air Force purchase.   "I have always seriously questioned the Air Force's real commitment to the JCA program. My skepticism will increase if it is confirmed that the Air Force has committed no funds to buy aircraft in the actual contract award, whatever they say they intend to buy," said Stephen Trimble, who writes the DEW Line blog on defense weapons issues.   Wall Street projections say the total JCA market could be 200 planes or more, if the U.S. adds more planes for the National Guard and starts a foreign military sales program. The Air Force is working this year on a study that may determine its long-term interest in the program.     -By Rebecca Christie, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9243; Rebecca.Christie@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 08:21 ET (12:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Borsa Italiana Board Backs London Stock Exchange Merger
Story: By Liam Moloney and Sabrina Cohen   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     MILAN (Dow Jones)--The board of Borsa Italiana SpA Saturday said it approved a EUR1.63 billion all-share takeover bid from the London Stock Exchange PLC (LSE.LN), marking a further step in the ongoing consolidation of stock exchanges worldwide.   Borsa Italiana executives, which met Friday, took two days to iron out details of the proposed new business which will be headed by current LSE Chief Executive Clara Furse, with Borsa Italiana CEO Massimo Capuano taking the deputy CEO role.   The tie-up "creates the leading diversified exchange group in Europe and the platform for additional strong growth on a European and global scale," the two companies said in a joint statement.   The two also said the combined group will provide "significant" benefits for customers and shareholders.   LSE is offering 4.90 of its own shares for each Borsa Italiana share. Borsa is unlisted and owned mainly by Italian banks.   The new group is valued at EUR5.78 billion based on Tuesday's closing price, the companies said.   The merger is expected to be earnings neutral to positive in financial year 2008, and at least 1% earnings accretive the following year, LSE and Borsa said.   LSE will have seven directors on the enlarged business's board, and Borsa Italiana will have five.   LSE had previously rejected several takeover offers from rival exchanges, including Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. (NDAQ), pan-European bourse operator Euronext - which has since merged with NYSE Group Inc. to create NYSE Euronext (NYX) - the Nordic exchange OMX (OMX.SK) and Deutsche Boerse AG (DB1.XE).   LSE and Borsa Italiana announced Wednesday they were discussing a merger. The deal will give the LSE greater weight in any future talks with its longtime suitor, Nasdaq. The New York-based company has twice pursued LSE and owns 30% of its shares.   Borsa Italiana also said its board met Thursday and Friday to discuss "other strategic alternatives and indicative proposals," without naming them, before accepting LSE's offer.   NYSE Euronext sent a rival offer to Milan on Thursday, a person familiar with the matter said.   Last year, Euronext talked to Borsa Italiana about merging but didn't reach an agreement. NYSE Euronext executives have said several times since that they are still open to forging a deal with the Milan-based bourse.   Borsa Italiana also held talks last year with Deutsche Boerse. Deutsche Boerse Chief Executive Reto Francioni told analysts Friday that he remains open to all forms of cooperation, but said there were no large acquisition "up its sleeve."   Francioni said his is now focused on growing organically and to complete the acquisition of the U.S. options exchange International Securities Exchange (ISE).   Last month Bank of Italy Governor Mario Draghi urged banks and other Borsa Italiana owners to clarify the exchange's growth strategy.   In 2006, Milan's EUR1.14 trillion-worth of total trades placed it fourth among European bourses, behind Euronext, the LSE and Deutsche Boerse.   An Italian deal would also give the LSE - which is predominantly an equities trading market - greater access to the European bond market. Borsa Italiana has exercised an option to buy NYSE Euronext's stake in their bond-trading joint venture   LSE also would get a business in derivatives, where it has struggled to get established.   The NYSE Euronext merger in April kicked off a wave of consolidation in the sector as established stock exchanges face increased competition for business, particularly in Europe where the E.U.'s Markets in Financial Instruments Directive, or MiFID, will from November this year allow the creation of alternative trading systems.   In November 2006, seven investment banks unveiled plans for a standalone stock trading platform called Project Turquoise. They aim to reduce their securities trading costs.   Also last year, nine investment banks announced plans for a trade and market data dissemination platform called Project Boat, aiming to reduce the individual banks' costs, which will arise with MiFID's requirements regarding post-trade transparency.   In May the Nasdaq made an agreed $3.7 billion bid for OMX.   A conference call on the LSE and Borsa link up is scheduled for 0800 GMT Monday.   Merrill Lynch (MER) and Lehman Brothers (LEH) advised LSE, while Morgan Stanley (MS) and Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) advised Borsa Italiana.     Company Web sites: http://www.londonstockexchange.com                      http://www.borsaitaliana.it     -By Liam Moloney and Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 339 4607390; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 06:54 ET (10:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Alliance Boots Pulls Out Of Europe Trade Group - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Alliance Boots PLC (AB.LN) has pulled out of a key European trade association after a row with its competitors over sweeping changes to the Europe's wholesale medicines market, The Times of London reported Saturday, citing a leaked letter from Ornella Barra, the company's wholesale affairs director.   The letter apparently shows that the company withdrew unilaterally from the European Association of Pharmaceutical Wholesalers on June 11, the newspaper said.   According to the Times, the decision followed a series of disagreements with the organization, which represents 600 of Europe's largest drug wholesalers, after Alliance Boots's exclusive distribution deal with Pfizer Inc. (PFE), the U.S. pharmaceutical giant, last year.   The association opposes the new drug distribution arrangements, which have cut out rival wholesalers by making Alliance Boots the exclusive supplier of all Pfizer medicines to every chemist and dispensing doctor in the UK, the Times reported.   According to the newspaper, Pfizer, which is seeking to reduce costs in the face of the expiry of patents on some of its bestselling drugs, has said that it is considering rolling out similar exclusive distribution deals across Europe.   Alliance Boots has also been Europe's largest pharmaceutical wholesaler, earning GBP9 billion of its GBP17 billion revenues from its wholesaling activities last year, the Times said.   The newspaper quoted a spokesman for Alliance Boots as confirming the decision to withdraw from the group, but declined further comment.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 07:04 ET (11:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) A Mortgage Meltdown For MBIA? -2-
Story: The full $170 million amount was made good by three European reinsurers. At the same time, MBIA entered into a reinsurance agreement on future business with the same reinsurers, guaranteeing them nearly $300 million in future premiums over a period of years. Subsequently, MBIA insisted that the $170 million in loss payments and the $297 million in future premiums wasn't a disguised loan agreement but two separate, bona fide reinsurance deals. The appeal of that interpretation was clear: If the opposite were true, then MBIA wouldn't have qualified for insurance-accounting treatment. Instead, it would've been required to take a $170 million charge, dinging 1998 earnings by 25% -- a serious blow to its dependable growth-stock image and its then much-ballyhooed claim of being a zero-loss underwriter. By virtue of a decorously long payback period, MBIA could both spread and bury the loss over seven years or more.   Finally, in early '05, the MBIA story began to unravel as a result of an aggressive joint investigation of the Aherf deal by the New York Attorney General's office, SEC and the U.S. Justice Department. Smoking guns abounded. Among other things, investigators turned up secret side agreements between MBIA and the reinsurers, leaving little doubt as to the true loan nature of the transaction.     MBIA agreed to pay fines and restitution of $75 million without "admitting or denying any wrongdoing." It also was required to hire and pay for an independent consultant to review the company's auditing, compliance and accounting procedures and investigate some other possibly suspect MBIA deals. In a posting on its Website, MBIA says that it doesn't "anticipate any further enforcement action with respect to any of the matters being reviewed by the Independent Consultant or with respect to any of the other matters that were under investigation."   That may be too optimistic. The consultant, John Siffert, is a tough former federal prosecutor in Manhattan who's now a civil and criminal litigator. And unless he has gone native during his MBIA probe, he should have plenty of grist for his mill in MBIA's handling of an investment it made in the late '90s in a municipal property-tax lien company called Capital Asset Research.   The Capital Asset contretemps began innocently enough, with MBIA's parent concern purchasing a 46% stake in the lien concern for just $15 million. But by 1998, just two years later, the company had gone haywire and MBIA was in deeply over its head. Just how badly came out at a Capital Asset directors' meeting when Gary Dunton, then MBIA chief investment officer and now chairman, president and CEO, was caught on videotape complaining to a fellow director that MBIA's exposure to Capital Asset's woes had ballooned to something like $500 million.   Two weeks earlier, the same Dunton had assured analysts on a conference call that MBIA had only about $140 million at risk in Capital Asset and three other municipal finance operations it had lumped into the same unit.   MBIA, which has not commented on the Capital Asset saga, ultimately suffered around a $300-million loss, but was able to delay recognition of $200 million of that over the next eight years or so by prevailing on its insurance unit to guarantee two securitizations of more than $300 million of Capital Asset's horribly-performing tax lien portfolio. The quality of one of the securitizations was so bad that MBIA whimsically dubbed it "Caulis Negris," an incorrect Latin translation of "black hole."   Such non-triple-A behavior for a time emboldened Pershing Square's Ackman and fellow shorts to think the unthinkable -- that perhaps the rating agencies like Moody's and S&P might decide to take away MBIA's vaunted credit rating. Such a move would be the proverbial knockout punch effectively putting the company out of business.   But that is highly unlikely. MBIA is one of the rating agencies' biggest revenue sources. They are also loath to call into question their triple-A ratings on the $635 billion par value of MBIA-guaranteed debt that's currently outstanding. A sudden markdown of that much debt could have calamitous legal and political repercussions for the rating-agency oligopoly.   So these days, Ackman and the other shorts have more modest ambitions. By constantly sounding the undercapitalization tocsin, they hope to starve the holding company by cutting off the flow of munificent upstream payments from the insurance unit that the parent has used to bolster the stock through fat dividend payments and large stock buybacks. Or even better, the shorts are hoping that a spiral in future claims losses might force the holding company to raise more equity and dilute shareholders.   If the subprime-mortgage market continues to unravel, the shorts might finally get a measure of solace.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Eni, Gazprom Sign MoU For Gas Pipeline, Capacity Undecided -2
Story: Eni Chief Executive Paolo Scaroni said at a press conference in Rome he expects the pipeline to provide the gas, should the feasibility study approve it, would take three years to build from when it receives all the necessary authorizations.   The CEO said the feasibility project will take "months," allowing the Italian company to envisage construction beginning in 2008 or the following year.   Scaroni told reporters he expects the pipeline price-tag to be in the "multi billion" U.S. dollar range but wasn't more specific.   The pipeline would be called "South Stream," the companies said.   Eni and Gazprom said the capacity will be determined in the feasibility study.   Gazprom Vice Chairman Alexander Medvedev, who was at the memorandum of understanding signing ceremony in Rome, said the yearly capacity of South Stream could be about 30 billion cubic meters.   Eni and Gazprom said the pipeline would link Russia and Bulgaria via an underwater line crossing the Black Sea.   The companies must decide if it then breaks into two lines, one heading north across Hungary to reach Central Europe, while the other across Greece and reaching Southern Italy.   Eni's CEO said they might decide with the feasibility study to build both lines rather than having to necessarily pick one of the two.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 09:38 ET (13:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Speaking Of Dividends: Open Palm
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   On June 4, Palm, maker of handheld computers and the Treo smartphone, announced a strategic relationship and a recapitalization plan to help it sharpen its competitive edge against the likes of Nokia, Research in Motion (which makes BlackBerry devices), Motorola, Samsung and Apple. Palm (ticker: PALM) plans to sell 25% of itself to private-equity firm Elevation Partners for $325 million of a new series of convertible preferred stock and to install Jon Rubenstein, who ran the iPod division of Apple from 2004 to 2006, as executive chairman. Palm also plans to pay its investors a $9 dividend.   Assuming green lights all around, the recapitalization is slated to close in the third quarter. Palm said the dividend, which would amount to approximately $940 million, is expected to be treated as a return of capital for most shareholders. That said to Robert Willens, a Lehman Brothers managing director and tax-accounting expert, that Palm "has no accumulated earnings and profits and expects to have no earnings and profits for 2007, the taxable year in which the distribution will be made." Elevation's contribution cannot be counted. ("Earnings and profits" is a tax-accounting concept designed to measure a corporation's dividend-paying capacity.) However, in the unlikely event that Palm generates at least $940 million of E&P this year, the entire distribution would instead be dividend income.   As it's more likely to be a return of capital, Willens explains that the dividend will not be included in the recipient's gross income but will instead be applied against, and reduce dollar for dollar, the basis (cost) of the stock on which the distribution is made. If the return of capital is in excess of that cost, the excess will be treated as a "gain from the sale or exchange of property" and therefore will be a capital gain.   Moreover, "it is generally conceded that the gain or loss on the return-of-capital distribution must be computed on a share-by-share basis." Accordingly, a shareholder with a combination of low-basis and higher basis blocks of Palm stock will have to recognize a gain on the portion of the distribution allocated to low-cost blocks even though the basis of the higher-cost blocks will not have been fully recovered.   As for dividend stripping, whereby short-term capital gains, taxed at 35%, are converted into qualified dividend income, taxed at 15%, forget about it. According to Willens, "a successful dividend strip can only arise where the distribution received is classified, in the first instance, as dividend income."   Noteworthy among last week's dividend announcements, Home Depot (HD) plans to buy back up to another $22.5 billion worth of its shares. That gives its current program a value of $40 billion, which shareholders hope will rev up the company's lackluster stock price. The world's No. 1 home-improvement retailer already has spent $16.5 billion on repurchases. It'll fund the buyback by selling its construction-supply business for $10.3 billion and by issuing $12 billion of senior unsecured notes. Although shareholder friendly, the action, in the face of the housing slowdown, prompted Standard & Poor's to place Home Depot's debt ratings on negative watch and Fitch Ratings to make downgrades. Home Depot pays a quarterly dividend of 22.5 cents a share and yields 2.26%.   GateHouse Media (GHS), one of the largest publishers of locally based print and online media across 20 states, hiked its quarterly common dividend for the second time this year, to 40 cents a share from 37 cents (up in March from 24 cents), for an 8.46% yield.   Darden Restaurants (DRI), the world's largest casual-dining company (the Olive Garden and Red Lobster chains are among its eateries), will now pay a quarterly dividend on its common of 18 cents a share, or 72 cents annually, versus a semiannual payout of 23 cents, or 46 cents a year. That's a 56.5% increase. Yield: 1.66%. Darden has spent $2.62 billion on stock buybacks since December 1995.   Winnebago Industries (WGO), one of the nation's biggest manufacturers of motor homes, boosted its quarterly payout to 12 cents a share from a dime and announced a new $60 million stock buyback. Since year- end 1997, the company has repurchased 24.4 million shares for some $356.8 million.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(6/23) Clear Channel Picks Arbitron's Radio-Ratings System
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Shira Ovide   In a major win for Arbitron Inc., Clear Channel Communications Inc. has agreed to a broad deal to use Arbitron's new electronic radio-ratings system, according to a person familiar with the deal.   The radio-station chain is expected to sign a multiyear agreement to subscribe to Arbitron's "portable people meter" -- or PPM -- system to measure radio audience. The contract covers the country's largest 50 radio markets, and ensures a wide adoption of the ratings system, which for the first time seeks to calculate electronically which radio stations people listen to and for how long.   The deal may end resistance to Arbitron's new ratings methodology. Radio companies, including Clear Channel, have complained the new system is too costly to them and uses flawed technology.   Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, may have had little choice but to embrace the PPM system. For years, advertising rates in radio have been tied to ratings calculated from people jotting down their listening habits in paper diaries. Advertisers have been pushing radio broadcasters and Arbitron to adopt more modern and accurate methodologies.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Pakistan s Privatization Commission Sells $650.3 Mln UBL GDRs
Story: ISLAMABAD (Dow Jones)--The Pakistan government priced United Bank Ltd.'s global depository receipts (GDRs) at $12.8543 each for a total of $650.3 million in a deal finalized Friday, a government official said Saturday.   "The government (of Pakistan) sold 202 million shares -  that is 25% of UBL (United Bank Ltd.) shares - which attracted $2.5 billion gross demand from Europe, Asia and Middle East," said Zahid Hamid, minister for privatization.   There was interest from 70 global investors, he said.   The GDRs will be listed on the London Stock Exchange on the basis of one GDR being worth four UBL shares valued at PKR195 each.   Conditional trading will start Monday. The first settlement of these GDRs will be executed on June 29, said Soofian Zuberi, managing director of Asia Equity Capital Markets for Merrill Lynch. Merrill Lynch was the sole book runner with local KASB securities.   The offer price represents a premium of 2.6% to the average price over 30 days, a premium of 9.2% to the average price over 60 days and a discount of about 5.3% to Friday's closing price of PKR206 a share.   UBL, the third largest bank in Pakistan, was privatized in October 2002 through a strategic sale in which 51% was transferred to the private sector along with management control.   The Abu Dhabi Group and Bestway Group each acquired 25.5% (132.09 million) of the shares each for a total price of PKR 12.3billion. The government held held the other 49%  before GDR issue.   The Privatization Commission is also issuing 5% shares with 2.5% green shoe option of Habib Bank Ltd. through an initial public offering on the local stock market. A total of 51.75 million shares at PKR235 each will size it at PKR12.2 billion ($203 million).   The offer will take place in two to three weeks through lead manager Global Securities.   Habib Bank, with 1,437 local and 40 overseas branches in 26 countries, is country's largest bank. A GDR issue of HBL will come in next two to three months.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 10:16 ET (14:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Follow-Up: Ingersoll: Industrial-Strength Stock
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   As Ingersoll-Rand slims down, interest in its stock is gaining some heft.   The Bermuda-based company's announcement in May that it could sell its cyclical Bobcat and construction-related operations and buy back shares sparked the stock (ticker: IR) to a high of 56 by last week. The stock has jumped 43% this year, easily outpacing the overall market and the machinery group. Speculation that Ingersoll-Rand itself could be bought is also fueling the rally.   Despite the run-up, Ingersoll remains a compelling play on industrial production and spirited spending on infrastructure projects across the globe. Ingersoll will use its copious cash flow to buy back stock, boosting earnings per share, and the likely sale of Bobcat should make the company a more consistent performer.   Furthermore, there's the potential that Ingersoll, free of the slumping Bobcat unit, could be snapped up by a private-equity company for at least 60 a share, according to some analysts.   Ingersoll's seven-year transformation into a diversified industrial outfit from a cyclical heavy-equipment maker may only now be winning fans, but Barron's highlighted the promise of the makeover two years ago ("Ingersoll-Rand: New and Improved," Aug. 1, 2005). The stock has since delivered a 47% return.   We believe the full benefits of the strategy have yet to be realized. So does Peter Bates, an industrials analyst with T. Rowe Price. "Stay in the stock," he advises. "If they stick to the game plan, it's still a good story."   One of the main tenets of that plan has been a muscular stock-repurchase program. After buying back $330 million worth of its shares under an authorization announced in December, management said last month that it would double the program to $4 billion. "Next year, they could have 40% of the company bought out internally," says Bates, who thinks the buyback could help boost earnings to about $5 a share in '09.   Affixing a price-to-earnings multiple of 13, he values Ingersoll-Rand at 65 a share, 16% higher than the current price. The Street is looking for Ingersoll to earn $3.51 a share this year and $3.95 in 2008.   Selling Bobcat would go a long way toward hitting those estimates; a divestiture could net $3.2 billion to $5 billion, say analysts. Ingersoll management wasn't available to comment, but in May the company said it was seeking "strategic alternatives" for the operation, including a sale or spinoff. Bear Stearns analyst Ann Duignan says a sale of Bobcat for $3.2 billion would generate $11 a share in cash, making the company an "attractive takeover candidate."   Even in the absence of a takeover, Ingersoll still holds appeal, say bulls. The Bobcat sale would solidify its transformation into a true diversified giant, worthy of the higher multiple typically afforded companies such as Illinois Tool Works (ITW). Bobcat, which makes construction equipment, has been hurt by the slumping housing market. Possible suitors: Volvo, Terex (TEX) and Deere (DE).   The "new" Ingersoll will be focused on refrigeration, security and industrial technologies, and be well-positioned to weather economic downturns, says T. Rowe's Bates. He thinks only 10%-15% of Ingersoll's earnings would "fall out of bed" in a recession.   Some investors worry that the company might make a big, costly acquisition. But the moves it has made so far have boosted shareholder value. Paying 16 times this year's earnings isn't too much to bet that it continues to do so.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) A Tough Sell
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Salesforce.com is the fastest-growing business-software company in the world, not to mention one hot stock. Yet the on-demand darling may have bitten off more than it can chew by taking on Oracle -- the biggest of the business-software bunch.   When Oracle reports earnings early this week, it's expected to disclose a head-to-head contract win or two over Salesforce (ticker: CRM) for large corporate customers. In effect, Oracle will be giving notice to its feisty rival-- which has less than 5% of Oracle's $14 billion in annual sales -- that it's ready to compete in selling robust on-demand customer-relations management software to top enterprise customers, says Cowen analyst Peter Goldmacher.   "Oracle is establishing a beachhead within Salesforce.com's high-end installed-customer base," says Goldmacher, who downgraded Salesforce to Neutral in April. He rates Oracle (ORCL) a Buy. Salesforce Chief Executive Marc Benioff told Barron's he didn't know of any big Oracle wins, but he wouldn't rule them out. Oracle wouldn't comment.   Salesforce shareholders should also take note. The stock has risen 88% in the past 52 weeks and has tripled since its initial public offering in June 2004. As the market digests more information about the challenge that Salesforce now faces, Goldmacher thinks the stock, a popular momentum play, could drop as much as 10%.   Goldmacher argues that the shares, trading at 45 times free cash flow, are pricey even taking into account the company's phenomenal growth. Salesforce's free cash flow has a compound annual growth rate of 31%, suggesting that the stock has outrun underlying growth. Another red flag: CEO Benioff has unloaded about 38% of his shares in the past two years.   Until 18 months ago, eight-year-old Salesforce rarely competed with Oracle, focusing on small and medium-sized businesses. But with great fanfare, Salesforce entered the enterprise market with a bang by landing deals with Cisco Systems, Dell, ADP and others.   By going after big corporate customers, Benioff also was testing his former boss, Oracle Chief Executive Larry Ellison, who isn't one to back down from a fight.   Benioff has revolutionized business software, especially sales-automation applications, by selling it as a computer service via the Internet rather than as software installed on a company's hardware.   On-demand software is expected to grow 20% to 25% annually over the next five years, compared with a 9%-to-12% rate for traditional enterprise software, says Chicago's William Blair & Co. Salesforce's system has been readily accepted by mom-and-pops because it's affordable and easy to deploy and use. But large companies have been reluctant clients because Salesforce's product sacrifices the ability to integrate and customize systems, Goldmacher explains. There's demand for both kinds of software, and  many  big customers want both, which should help Oracle defend its turf, Goldmacher says.   Through its 2006 acquisition of Siebel Systems, which practically invented customer-relationship software, Oracle became the dominant provider to large customers. But Siebel's pre-Oracle on-demand products delivered over the Internet fell short, giving Salesforce a big opening.     Oracle has been working hard in the past 18 months to develop an improved offering: Oracle CRM On Demand. Goldmacher says the completed application is up and running in an Oracle data center and is being sold. He predicts Siebel users will give it a try because it complements their previous investments in Siebel applications, integrates easily and doesn't come from a new vendor.   Price is another potential pitfall for Salesforce. Goldmacher contends that Salesforce, which already has a high cost of sales, is heavily discounting its deals to enterprise customers. Salesforce charges, on average, about $75 a month per user for its core small-business customers but fetches as little as $25 a month per user for enterprise customers, Goldmacher says. Benioff would not disclose average prices per customer.   The trouble is that Salesforce has been buying growth with little added profit. Sales soared 60% to $554.8 million in fiscal 2007 (ended Jan. 31), but margins grew only 1%, Goldmacher says. More discounted enterprise deals would pressure margins further, the analyst says.   Yet if Salesforce intends to compete for big corporate customers, it will need to continue to slash prices. If Salesforce were to get anything close to its average-price-per customer for a big client like Merrill Lynch with 25,000 users, the brokerage's price would be $20 million a year or so. "For that kind of money, Oracle would sell you all of the [CRM] software it has, and Larry [Ellison] would come over and install it himself," Goldmacher argues.   Between Oracle's revamped on-demand service, its advantage in bundling software for big customers and Salesforce's heavy discounting, Goldmacher thinks that picking a fight with Oracle and Ellison was a mistake: "Their enterprise strategy is fatally flawed," he says.   Benioff disagrees. Pointing to the quality of his enterprise-CRM customers like Cisco, he argues that seeking enterprise business was a wise move. To suggest otherwise is "insanity," he says. "Enterprise is not a zero-sum game; you don't have to win every deal," Benioff says.   Aside from his other challenges, Microsoft is expected to enter the on-demand business-software market in late summer, with a new CRM service that's code-named Titan, which will compete directly against Salesforce.   After having the small-business market mostly to itself, Salesforce will be battling Oracle on one front and Microsoft on another. That isn't easy.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Running Its Own Boston Marathon
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   You'd think a guy running a business catering to the world's biggest institutional investors would coddle his shareholders a little more. But in February, State Street CEO Ronald Logue went ahead with the $4.5 billion stock-based acquisition of smaller Boston rival Investors Financial Services knowing that it would snatch about 14 cents a share from this year's earnings. The decision cut short an extended rise in the banking company's stock as investors bolted: The sharesfell 13% in the weeks after the news. Wall Street didn't like the 38% premium Logue was paying for a second-tier custody outfit that would reduce State Street's near-term performance.   Several months later, the 61-year old Boston native hasn't changed his longer-term view of the deal's value, which he anticipates will add 10 cents a share to earnings by 2009. "We believe that it will be revenue growth that will separate the men from the boys in our business," he tells Barron's. "It's all about keeping customers and finding ways to do more business." Logue confidently projects that State Street (ticker: STT) will retain 90% of Investors Financial's (IFIN) customers.   Such a well-informed streak of independence is refreshing in a CEO, even if it doesn't always make him popular.  "Shareholders are furious with the company, believing they don't care about the short term and the dilution," says Richard Bove, an analyst at broker Punk Ziegel. "They don't. The acquisition has only enhanced their superb international position."   The investor unhappiness has only enhanced the value in the shares. Although the price has rebounded, it's still flat for the year, underperforming the S&P 500's 7% gain. The shares are  trading at a multiple of 16 times 2008 earnings projections, well below their typical 20 times forward estimates.   "The lower multiple certainly creates a buying opportunity," says Bove, who's got an $85 target on the stock, more than 20% above last week's level.     The dust-up over IFIN aside, State Street has a lot going for it these days. Its servicing unit, which will absorb IFIN and accounts for 80% of revenues, provides everything from accounting to securities lending to foreign-exchange research to custody and administration services for major institutions like Axa Financial, the California Public Employees Retirement System, Pimco and Putnam. As a result, its shares are a play on the global expansion of the capital markets, the proliferation of hedge funds and the outsourcing of non-core financial services. State Street's high-margin asset-management group, which kicks in 20% of revenues, is the biggest money manager in the world, overseeing the second biggest index-fund complex along with thriving active money-management and ETF operations.   "Our secret weapon is focus," says Logue, who leads a bank-holding company that doesn't offer much in the way of traditional banking services. "This is all we do. I have no commercial banker, no branch banker coming through that door asking me for money. All the investment goes into the business. . . . Virtually all the other organizations have competing influences for investment. We only do two businesses: asset management and asset servicing."   That makes it a far different sort of bank than, say, Citigroup (C), which has struggled to get its multi-faceted global financial supermarket in synch.   The model has worked well, allowing State Street to exceed its objectives. It targets annual growth in operating earnings per share of between 8% and 10%, top-line revenue expansion of 16% to 18% and return on equity of between 12% and 15%. Last year EPS rose 16%, revenue gained 15% and return on equity came to 17%. Revenue totaled $6.3 billion in 2006, with earnings of $1.1 billion. The consensus calls for $7.3 billion in 2007 revenues and $1.3 billion in profits, gains of 16% and 18%, respectively.  The company's shares have risen 75% in the last four years.   At its core, State Street is a technology provider with deep, longstanding relationships at major financial institutions. In fact, it's sometimes been criticized for spending too much -- about 22% of expenses in 2006 -- on more powerful computer systems. But that has allowed it to build a superior global platform that handles more and more transactions. Fully 15% of the world's securities trades -- cleared in shorter and shorter time periods -- go through State Street's computer networks.   "Assets under custody no longer means what it once did," says Logue, who's credited with unifying State Street's executive team since taking the top spot in 2004 after a bout of nasty corporate infighting. "Global management has become so complex that the real benchmark of success comes from the amount of revenue you can draw from each client."   State Street is doing what it can to bombard them with every sort of record- and score-keeping service, usually in competition with its main custody rivals, the soon-to-merge Bank of New York (BK) and Mellon Financial (MEL)   Money-management arm State Street Global Advisors has seen its index operations grow to $714 billion today as investors have wearied of paying higher fees for mediocre returns from actively-managed funds. SSGA has also ridden the wave of enthusiasm for exchange-traded funds by launching 83 of them, including the world's first and still biggest, the Spider, traded on the American Stock Exchange. In all it now runs $115 billion in ETF assets. Although known as an indexer, SSGA has also built a formidable active-management group that now oversees $188 billion in assets, including $4.5 billion in hedge funds.   While much smaller in revenue, asset management's healthy pretax margins of 35% dwarf servicing's 26%. As always, State Street stands ready to exploit the next professional money-management trend.     But investor worries about the IFIN deal, expected to close next month, have obscured some of this promise. Management is convinced the transaction fits its strategy of cross-selling many products to a core-client base that it's trying to expand.   "Investors Financial serves 12 of the top 25 global investment managers, who will now have access to State Street's continuous global asset management and custody accounting as well as foreign exchange, securities lending and other ancillary services," says Jay Hooley, vice chairman and head of global securities servicing.   State Street, which has been one of the leading consolidators in the custody market, expects to squeeze as much as a 50% reduction in expenses from IFIN while raising revenues by offering the new clients its full array of services.   Reeling in its Boston neighbor isn't expected to be a big problem. A decade ago, State Street bought the $1.9 trillion asset- servicing arm of Deutsche Bank: It rationalized the German bank's eight legacy systems to get a 35% cost savings, while keeping almost 90% of customers.   "We're using the same blueprint complete with the same people," Logue explains. "You make decisions quickly so the customers know what's happening and retain as many customer-facing people from the acquired entity as possible."   Once complete, the deal will give State Street added heft in mutual-fund custody and will deliver more administration and servicing clients within the fast-growing hedge-fund world. IFIN also has a solid constituency among private-equity funds, handling about $60 billion in assets.   Perhaps most important, the acquisition helps realize State Street's desire to expand internationally, where it sees growth rates nearly double those of the U.S. over the next few years. IFIN had $35 billion among offshore funds.   There is one potential hitch: Asset-management rival Barclays Financial is a big IFIN custody customer that State Street will have to figure out how to retain.     Obviously, State Street's fortunes are closely tied to the health of the world's capital markets. If transaction volumes fall, State Street's revenues and profits fall, too, though not as much as participants with more direct market exposure.   State Street is otherwise in an excellent spot to benefit if, as expected, the world's capital markets expand over time and global money flows become more interconnected. It has a deep reservoir of contacts to draw upon. A remarkable 80% of the firm's new revenue comes from existing customers; its 25 top customers have been clients for an average of 19 years and typically use 15 products.   Even if Wall Street doesn't always agree with his moves, Logue plans to keep pushing State Street to be a survivor. "At the end of the day, there are only going to be two or three of us left" in the custody-bank business, says Logue. "My belief is that large commercial universal banks will not be in that business. It's only a small portion of their overall activity. And it requires so much focus." And focus, long term, is what he and State Street are good at.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: That unit accounts for just 5.5% of its $3 billion in revenue but generates the bulk of its bad press, and a relatively scandal-free 2006 election season opens a window for Diebold to find a buyer. Headline: India SEBI Suspends Karvy's License For Role In IPO Scam
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--The Securities & Exchange Board of India has suspended the license of local brokerage Karvy Stock Broking Ltd. for three months and also prohibited it from opening any new dematerialized accounts until the end of 2007 due to irregularities in its dealings in the initial public offering of companies such as Yes Bank Ltd. (532648.BY) and Infrastructure Development Financing Corp. Ltd. (532659.BY).   "The direction (on demat accounts) will come into force with immediate effect," domestic capital markets regulator SEBI's whole-time member G. Anantharaman said in an order issued late Friday night.   The order on the suspension of membership will beeffective after 21 daysfrom the date of the order, Anantharaman's order added.   Karvy is a member of the Bombay Stock Exchange, the National Stock Exchange and the Hyderabad Stock Exchange.   Further, company division Karvy Computershare Pvt. Ltd. has also been prohibited from acting as a registrar to issues for nine months.   "As Karvy Computershare Pvt. Ltd. had already undergone the prohibition for that period vide Securities and Exchange Board of India order dated April 27, 2006, there will be no further directions against Karvy Computershare Pvt. Ltd.," SEBI said.   The order came after an investigation into Karvy's role in the IPO process, specifically its share allotment procedure after book building.   Last year, a SEBI inquiry had found that some individuals garnered a substantial share of stocks reserved for small investors in the IPOs of IDFC and Yes Bank by making multiple applications as small investors.     -By Romit Guha, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 04:01 ET (08:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) European Trader: The Trouble With Rose-Colored Sunglasses
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sean Walters and Rod Stone   At first glance, Luxottica Group's takeover of Oakley, the maker of sporty sunglasses, looks good for the Italian group. But the purchase actually carries some serious risks.   It can't be taken for granted that Luxottica, which up to now has focused its retailing efforts on fashion brands, can translate its expertise to a sports brand.   The trend for luxury-goods manufacturers to expand their portfolios to include sports brands was highlighted by PPR's (ticker: PP.France) recent takeover of Puma. But it's too early to say that what looks good in theory will work in practice.   Another worry for Luxottica (LUX.Italy) is that its heavy exposure to the North American retail market -- it operates the LenCrafters and Pearle Vision retail chains -- won't be remedied by the acquisition of U.S.-based Oakley (OO).   Over 80% of Luxottica's retail outlets are already in the States and Canada, which provide a substantial amount of its revenue. Adding Oakley's existing retail operation will do nothing to reduce this imbalance and minimize the risk. Oakley, with headquarters in Foothill Ranch, Calif., is similarly dependent on the North American market.   Indeed, putting more eggs in one geographical basket looks particularly odd because Luxottica has stated that it's looking for takeover targets worldwide. As a global organization with an appetite for acquisitions, Luxottica would do well to look toward other locations for future purchases, ones that will provide better opportunities for growth.   Yet the incorporation of Oakley's operations into Luxottica's seems to make enough financial sense that investors have immediately warmed to the deal, based on the cost savings from the companies' overlap as sunglass makers. Luxottica's stock was up 3.8% for the week, to 27.82 euros a share.   The proposed savings over three years are equivalent to $932 million in today's money. This is higher than the $663 million premium paid for the company.   On top of that, the difference in the profit margins of the two companies -- 9.4% for Luxottica and 5.9% for Oakley -- suggests that there's ample room for Luxottica to squeeze out better returns from its acquisition.   That said, the jury is surely out on whether Luxottica has the ability to manage the Oakley brand better than its current management has done.   Luxottica is paying a fairly full price for Oakley -- nearly 15 times estimated 2007 earnings, compared with the 12 multiple on PPR's purchase of Puma. But if Luxottica does figure out how to sell into the sports sector more effectively than Oakley has, the deal will make sound sense.     Airbus may have grabbed the headlines at this year's Paris Air Show, but it's worth noting the strong performance of Rolls-Royce (RR.U.K.). The British company secured civil- and military-engine deals worth more than $15 billion at catalog prices, helped in particular by its models for new wide-bodied passenger aircraft.   It has benefitted from being the sole current supplier of engines on the new A350 XWB, for which Airbus secured 141 firm orders last week. Rolls-Royce is also one of two suppliers for Boeing's (BA) new fuel-efficient 787, which is due to make its first flight this year, and for Airbus' long-delayed A380 double-decker.   While engine sales are swelling the order book, it's over the long term that shareholders will see the real benefits. Engine makers typically achieve better profit margins on spares and maintenance than on new sales. These orders therefore are crucial for the long-term fortunes of the company.   Rolls-Royce has been pushing more and more customers into its "TotalCare" package, which helps airlines remove uncertainties over their engine-servicing costs. Airlines pay an agreed-upon rate for each flying hour in return for 24-hour support. The company now generates some 59% of its commercial aerospace engine revenue from such after-market activities.   At the end of 2006, Rolls-Royce had some 12,000 engines operating around the world and expects this to hit about 15,500 by 2010 -- some three years before the A350 is due to enter service.   A major hole in Rolls-Royce's portfolio is that it doesn't supply engines for Boeing's strong-selling single-aisle 737. However, Rolls-Royce's exposure to the new wide-bodied jet programs should stand it in good stead when it looks to supply engines for both Boeing and Airbus' next generation of single-aisle planes, due around 2015 at the earliest.   The long-term outlook for the maintenance business should also reassure investors. Rolls' stock, already up 36% in the past 12 months, to 46 British pounds, may well continue its ascent.   ---   Sean Walters and Rod Stone are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                        DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global           DJ Global           DJ Global     Point      Indexes,            Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Boeing Sees Hope For Future Combat Systems In 2008 US Budget
Story: By Rebecca Christie     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     PARIS (Dow Jones)--Boeing Co. (BA) is optimistic that the U.S. Army's $162 billion Future Combat Systems program will escape devastating cuts in next year's defense budget.   The House of Representatives is weighing a proposal to cut $867 million from the Army's 2008 request. The move would effectively scrap development on the manned ground vehicles at the heart of the Boeing-led project, which also is developing a range of computer networks, communications systems and battlefield drones.   But the Senate hasn't embraced cuts on any similar scale, and a proposal this year would even add money to the FCS request. Also, Army support for the program hasn't wavered despite changes in its its civilian and military leadership.   As a result, Boeing is optimistic that the vehicles will stay in the development plan, said Roger Krone, president of Boeing's networks and space systems unit, in an interview at the Paris Air Show. He said concern for troops will convince lawmakers to keep ground vehicles in the plan, despite pressure to fund other programs and also keep a close eye on Boeing as lead systems integrator.   If the manned ground vehicles get cut, "the soldiers who are out on patrol will be going around in vehicles that were designed 30 and 40 years ago," Krone said.   "If we don't move forward with the manned ground vehicles, that's exactly where the Army will be, and that is why in discussions that I have been party to with the House, they've said we're not going to cut the manned ground vehicle," Krone said.   -By Rebecca Christie, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9243; Rebecca.Christie@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 16:56 ET (20:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 2nd UPDATE: Santander Chief Sees 07 Pft Up 21%, Highest Ever
Story: (Updates item from 1019 GMT with details on the change of the bank's official name.)     By Christopher Bjork   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     SANTANDER, Spain (Dow Jones)--Spain's Santander Central Hispano SA (STD) expects ordinary net profit to grow 21% this year, Chairman Emilio Botin said Saturday during the bank's annual general meeting.   Botin told shareholders that his bank, Spain's largest by assets, is on its way to a record result in 2007. He said he expects Santander to reach a 2007 net profit - excluding extraordinary gains - of more than EUR8 billion, compared with EUR6.58 billion in the same period last year.   "Santander is well positioned to continue to grow more than its competitors," the 73-year-old Santander chief said.   "We have an outstanding position today because we have combined a strategy of organic, sustainable and recurrent growth with corporate transactions throughout our history."   Botin said Santander will call an extraordinary general meeting for July 27 to ask shareholders to approve a EUR9 billion equity issue as part of its plan to buy about a third of ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN).   Santander is part of a trio of European banks trying to take over and split the Dutch bank between them, and has said it is willing to pay EUR19.9 billion in cash and shares for ABN's Brazilian and Italian units.   "For Santander, there are very clear advantages to this transaction which, if it occurs, will enable us to buy some very interesting assets," he added.   A successful bid for the ABN Amro units would give Santander a solid foothold in Italy, and give it control of the third-largest banking network in Brazil.   The bidding group, which includes Santander's long-time business partner Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS.LN)and Fortis NV (FORSY), has outlined a EUR71.1 billion ($96 billion) offer for ABN Amro.   The proposed offer, the biggest ever in the banking industry, is competing with a friendly, lower, bid for the Dutch bank made by Barclays PLC (BCS).   At Saturday's meeting, held in its northern Spanish home city of Santander, Botin said he was still optimistic about global economic conditions.   "We believe that the boom has not yet come to an end," Botin said. "We will have somewhat higher interest rates, markets may become more volatile and growth may slow in some economies. but global expansion, already in its longest phase in 35 years, is built on a very broad base."    Santander, with a market capitalization of slightly more than EUR85 billion, is the euro zone's largest bank by market value. It also controls the largest banking franchise in Latin America and a big U.K. lender.   On Spain, Botin said the red-hot housing market had begun a healthy cooling process. "A slowing of growth has begun, which is positive, good even."   Like its rival Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA (BBV), Santander is profiting from the resurgent economies in Latin America, which are in their fourth consecutive year of balanced growth. Exposure to these markets has helped make Santander and BBVA two of Europe's fastest-growing banks.   Botin said he was optimistic about the region's outlook for the rest of the year.   After a strong share performance last year, when the stock rose 27%, Santander shares are down around 1% so far this year, while the the Spanish benchmark index IBEX-35 is up about 5%. Uncertainty related to the offer for ABN Amro is weighing on the share price, analysts say.   Botin said that he was optimistic about the stock in the medium term. "Remember what happened with Abbey: the market initially punished us, but then went on to reward our strategy," Botin said, referring to Santander's 2004 purchase of U.K. mortgage lender Abbey National.   Ibersecurities analyst Mario Lodos, who has a buy rating on the stock, said that the 2007 target looked ambitious.   "I think it's doable, but many investors are gonna be skeptical that they can reach such a figure, which would be the highest in the euro zone," Lodos said.   Botin added that Santander will pay on August 1 a first dividend on 2007 results of EUR0.12294, 15% higher than its first dividend in 2006.   In the first quarter, Santander posted a 21% rise in net profit to EUR1.9 billion, backed by strong growth at its main businesses in Latin America, Spain and the U.K.   During Saturday's AGM, shareholders also voted in favor of changing the bank's official name to Banco Santander SA.   The bank, which is celebrating its 150th anniversary this year, is unifying its brand around the world, gradually phasing out the names of the banks it has bought in the past and focusing on the Santander brand.   Company Web site: http://www.santander.com     -By Christopher Bjork, Dow Jones Newswires, +34 91 395 81 23, christopher.bjork@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 07:59 ET (11:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Turkey's TSKB,Halkbank Secure EUR200M Loans From World Bk-IHA
Story: ANKARA (Dow Jones)--The Turkish Treasury said late Friday that Turkiye Sinai Kalkinma Bankasi A.S. (TSKB.IS), or TSKB, and Turkiye Halk Bankasi A.S. (THALK.IS), or Halkbank, each secured a EUR200 million loan from the World Bank, under the guarantee of the Treasury, the Ihlas News Agency, or IHA, reported Saturday.   The Treasury said the Board of Directors of the World Bank approved the deal June 19 and it was signed June 22.   The 15-year loans, which have a five-year grace period, will be used for the Financing Small and Medium Sized Enterprises Project.   Each bank will provide EUR100 million in loans directly to the small and medium-sized enterprises. Of the loan that Halkbank received, EUR25 million will be disbursed to small and medium-sized enterprises based in the Central and Southeastern regions of Turkey.     Agency Web sites: http://www.ihavideo.net and http://www.iha.com.tr     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 06:49 ET (10:49 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Plugged In: Verizon: Game Day Is Here
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   What does Verizon Communication's chief executive, Ivan Seidenberg, really think of the Apple iPhone?   Seidenberg says he's "excited" about the new smartphone, which will be carried exclusively by his rival wireless competitor AT&T at the end of this month.   And when asked whether he thought Apple (ticker: AAPL) could reach its modest targets of selling 10 million iPhone units by 2008, he answered, yes: "Why would I have any other view on it?"   Seidenberg, who held a news conference after his speech last week at the NXTcomm telecommunication conference in Chicago, used the sarcastic tone favored by football coaches during the week of the big game when the other team is favored to win. He said all the right things, but you sensed it was a tad disingenuous, making one wonder what was really rattling through his head.   Sticking to his pre-game script, the CEO went on to say that the iPhone's emphasis on music, video and the Web would "energize" the entire business, including the video, music and data services offered by Verizon (VZ). "I am actually hoping that the Apple iPhone will do reasonably well," he told reporters.   No matter how many kisses he tossed AT&T's (T) way, the reporters would not let him off the hook. Finally, Seidenberg let his guard down, saying that Verizon has been the incumbent wireless champion for 10 or so years through organic growth (as opposed to AT&T's more acquisitive expansion). "We think that we're the premier wireless carrier," Seidenberg declared.   Then, sounding more like a coach who finished first in the regular season standings but wasn't getting any respect, he said: "I think the burden is on them to prove that the market will change" before Verizon needs to do anything dramatic -- such as introduce a so-called iPhone killer that can compete with the much-hyped handset.   Verizon has been blazing its own trail in mobile music and video through its V Cast services and Chocolate multi-media phones made by Korea's LG Electronics (066570.Korea), which are expected to get a refreshed design in July. The company's recently launched V Cast mobile video services, which are based on Qualcomm's (QCOM) MediaFLo technology, will be available in 40 cities by July and 120 markets by the end of the year.   In the meantime, the Verizon CEO seems to think it's time for AT&T and Apple to stop the pre-game chatter and prove what they can do on the field. Says Seidenberg: "You've got to buy your ticket and show up for the game."     The watchword of the Chicago confab was "convergence." The so-called triple-play packages offered by cable companies and traditional phone carriers, which often bundle phone, television and broadband services -- are likely to become quadruple plays with the inclusion of wireless services.   The addition of wireless coupled with the anticipated explosion in mobile video, games and Web surfing is going to hasten demand for broadband bandwidth. Cisco Systems' Chief Executive John Chambers couldn't be happier that Internet network capacity will probably need to grow 300% to 500% a year to keep pace. Cisco (CSCO) supplies the plumbing fixtures of the pipeline, such as routers and switches. Even that may not be enough for Chambers, who says: "We need to make the definition of broadband broader."   ---   e-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Vice Chmn Says EU Gas Unbundling Is 'Painful' Issue
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--Alexander Medvedev, vice chairman of Russia's OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS), said Saturday a European Union proposal to split the production and distribution infrastructure of gas companies is a "painful" issue, indicating the company's strong opposition to it.   This proposal "is in conflict with rules of the market economy," said Medvedev, adding that these allow producers of end-products to sell them to consumers.   The Gazprom executive was speaking at a press conference in Rome for the signing of a memorandum of understanding with Eni SpA (E) on the possibility of the two companies building a new pipeline called "South Stream" to bring Russian gas to the E.U.   Medvedev said the E.U. proposal is also facing the opposition of some member states. France is among the countries in the 27-nation bloc that have criticized the plan.   E.U. Competition Commissioner Neelie Kroes said on June 15 that Gazprom would have to sell its distribution assets in eastern Europe if a plan to reform the energy industry is approved.   Under the plan, which was unveiled in January, the E.U. would force energy companies to separate production and distribution units in order to boost competition. This process is also known as unbundling.     -By Liam Moloney, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 678 2543; liam.moloney@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 12:35 ET (16:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/25) Follow-Up: Will Yahoo! Get Bought Out?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   For all the uncertainties Yahoo! faces, its stock is almost sure to rise.   Last week's departure of Terry Semel as chief executive could be the first step toward a sale or breakup of the Web giant (ticker: YHOO), which has lost critical market share to Google (GOOG) in search advertising and is seeing its dominant position in display ads pressured. Alternatively, co-founder and returning CEO Jerry Yang could reinvigorate the Internet service provider. "Any way you look at it, the stock goes up from here," says Larry Haverty of Gabelli Global Multimedia. "It is very good value."   Trading at 27.60, Yahoo! shares are modestly below the 29 where they stood when we presented a bullish picture last year ("Yahoo!'s Edge,") May 22, 2006). We argued that interest in Google had led investors to overlook a lot of Yahoo!'s strengths, including the facts that it has the biggest audience on the Web, is the leader in Internet display ads and generates a ton of cash.   What we didn't know at the time was how far behind Yahoo! was in Project Panama, its effort to upgrade its search engine, to boost profitability and better compete with Google.   The long delay ultimately allowed Google to run away with market share. In May, Google accounted for 56.3% of all Internet searches, compared with 21.5% for Yahoo! Only late in the first quarter of this year did Yahoo! finally launch the much-anticipated search upgrade.   The shares climbed as high as $33.74 after our story, then slumped to a low of $22.65, as buoyant expectations gave way to bitter disappointment time and again. Indeed, overshadowed by the announcement that Semel would step down as CEO (he remains non-executive chairman) was Yahoo!'s warning that second-quarter results would fall short of forecasts. The company said that improvements in search-advertising would be offset by a slowdown in display advertising and weakness in its affiliate network.   Certainly, the company is more vulnerable. If it can't find its footing, there's no doubt in some investors' minds that it will be sold outright to a Microsoft (MSFT) or News Corp. (NWS.A). Microsoft and Yahoo! have held informal discussions in the past and News Corp. has been said to be contemplating a swap of its MySpace social networking unit for a 25% stake in Yahoo! There's also been talk of a bid by Yahoo! and a member of its board, Ron Burkle and his holding company, Yucaipa, for Dow Jones (DJ), publisher of Barron's, but no such bid has emerged and most observers are skeptical.   Some investors would like to see a private-equity style deal in which Yahoo! sells strategic assets and strips itself down to its core business of providing niche Websites for everything from autos to entertainment to sports. One hedge-fund investor holding Yahoo! shares envisions a deal -- similar to Google's pact with MySpace -- in which the company outsources its search function to Google for $10 billion to $15 billion. That would save Yahoo! hundreds of millions in operating and capital expenses. Then, this investor says, it could sell Yahoo! Japan for roughly $7 billion. Yahoo! would then be free to focus on its business of building the best niche destination sites, potentially buying Website companies like Bankrate, Monster Worldwide, WebMd and Expedia.   Others, however, insist that the best way to maximize shareholder value is an outright sale. Haverty sees Yahoo! shares fetching in the upper 30s in a sale.   Right now, based on 2009 estimated cash flow, Yahoo! trades at only a slight premium to newspaper companies. Even with all the company's troubles, that just doesn't make sense.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 23, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
